title: What is Mistral AI? Everything to know about the OpenAI competitor | TechCrunch
text:
Latest AI Amazon Apps Biotech & Health Climate Cloud Computing Commerce Crypto Enterprise EVs Fintech Fundraising Gadgets Gaming Google Government & Policy Hardware Instagram Layoffs Media & Entertainment Meta Microsoft Privacy Robotics Security Social Space Startups TikTok Transportation Venture Events Startup Battlefield StrictlyVC Newsletters Podcasts Videos Partner Content TechCrunch Brand Studio Crunchboard Contact Us Mistral AI, the French company behind AI assistant Le Chat and several foundational models, is officially regarded as one of France’s most promising tech startups and is arguably the only European company that could compete with OpenAI. But compared to its $6 billion valuation, its global market share is still relatively low. However, the recent launch of its chat assistant on mobile app stores was met with some hype, particularly in its home country. “Go and download Le Chat, which is made by Mistral, rather than ChatGPT by OpenAI — or something else,” French president Emmanuel Macron said in a TV interview ahead of the AI Action Summit in Paris. While this wave of attention may be encouraging, Mistral AI still faces challenges in competing with the likes of OpenAI — and in doing so while keeping up with its self-definition as “the world’s greenest and leading independent AI lab.” Mistral AI has raised significant amounts of funding since its creation in 2023 with the ambition to “put frontier AI in the hands of everyone.” While this isn’t a direct jab at OpenAI, the slogan is meant to highlight the company’s advocacy for openness in AI. Its alternative to ChatGPT, chat assistant Le Chat, is now also available on iOS and Android. It reached 1 million downloads in the two weeks following its mobile release, even grabbing France’s top spot for free downloads on the iOS App Store. This comes in addition to Mistral AI’s suite of models, which includes: Mistral AI’s three founders share a background in AI research at major U.S. tech companies with significant operations in Paris. CEO Arthur Mensch used to work at Google’s DeepMind, while CTO Timothée Lacroix and chief scientist officer Guillaume Lample are former Meta staffers. Co-founding advisers also include Jean-Charles Samuelian-Werve (also a board member) and Charles Gorintin from health insurance startup Alan, as well as former digital minister Cédric O, which caused controversy due to his previous role. Not all of them. Mistral AI differentiates its premier models, whose weights are not available for commercial purposes, from its free models, for which it provides weight access under the Apache 2.0 license. Free models include research models such as Mistral NeMo, which was built in collaboration with Nvidia that the startup open-sourced in July 2024. While many of Mistral AI’s offerings are free or now have free tiers, Mistral AI plans to drive some revenue from Le Chat’s paid tiers. Introduced in February 2025, Le Chat’s Pro plan is priced at $14.99 a month. On the purely B2B side, Mistral AI monetizes its premier models through APIs with usage-based pricing. Enterprises can also license these models, and the company likely also generates a significant share of its revenue from its strategic partnerships, some of which it highlighted during the Paris AI Summit. Overall, however, Mistral AI’s revenue is reportedly still in the eight-digit range, according to multiple sources. In 2024, Mistral AI entered a deal with Microsoft that included a strategic partnership for distributing its AI models through Microsoft’s Azure platform and a €15 million investment. The U.K.’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) swiftly concluded that the deal didn’t qualify for investigation due to its small size. However, it also sparked some criticism in the EU. In January 2025, Mistral AI signed a deal with press agency Agence France-Presse (AFP) to let Chat query the AFP’s entire text archive dating back to 1983. Mistral AI also secured strategic partnerships with France’s army and job agency, German defense tech startup Helsing, IBM, Orange, and Stellantis. As of February 2025, Mistral AI raised around €1 billion in capital to date, approximately $1.04 billion at the current exchange rate. This includes some debt financing, as well as several equity financing rounds raised in close succession. In June 2023, and before it even released its first models, Mistral AI raised a record $112 million seed round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners. Sources at the time said the seed round — Europe’s largest ever — valued the then-one-month-old startup at $260 million. Other investors in this seed round included Bpifrance, Eric Schmidt, Exor Ventures, First Minute Capital, Headline, JCDecaux Holding, La Famiglia, LocalGlobe, Motier Ventures, Rodolphe Saadé, Sofina, and Xavier Niel. Only six months later, it closed a Series A of €385 million ($415 million at the time), at a reported valuation of $2 billion. The round was led by Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), with participation from existing backer Lightspeed, as well as BNP Paribas, CMA-CGM, Conviction, Elad Gil, General Catalyst, and Salesforce. The $16.3 million convertible investment that Microsoft made in Mistral AI as part of their partnership announced in February 2024 was presented as a Series A extension, implying an unchanged valuation. In June 2024, Mistral AI then raised €600 million in a mix of equity and debt (around $640 million at the exchange rate at the time). The long-rumored round was led by General Catalyst at a $6 billion valuation, with notable investors, including Cisco, IBM, Nvidia, Samsung Venture Investment Corporation, and others. Mistral is “not for sale,” Mensch said in January 2025 at the World Economic Forum in Davos. “Of course, [an IPO is] the plan.” This makes sense, given how much the startup has raised so far: Even a large sale may not provide high enough multiples for its investors, not to mention sovereignty concerns depending on the acquirer. However, the only way to definitely squash persistent acquisition rumors is to scale its revenue to levels that could even remotely justify its nearly $6 billion valuation. Either way, stay tuned. As a freelance reporter at TechCrunch since 2021, she has covered a large range of startup-related topics including AI, fintech & insurtech, SaaS & pricing, and global venture capital trends.

As of 2025, her reporting for TechCrunch mostly focuses on Europe, and particularly on the rise of defense, security and resilience tech in the region.
She also writes TechCrunch’s Startups Weekly newsletter, rounding up startup news every Friday.

Anna has moderated panels and conducted onstage interviews at industry events of all sizes, including major tech conferences such as TechCrunch Disrupt, 4YFN, South Summit, TNW Conference, VivaTech, and many more.

A former LATAM & Media Editor at The Next Web, startup founder and Sciences Po Paris alum, she’s fluent in multiple languages, including French, English, Spanish and Brazilian Portuguese. title: Good hype for fusion, bad buzz for YC | TechCrunch
text:
Latest h FundraisAI Amazon Apps Biotech & Health Climate Cloud Computing Commerce Crypto Enterprise EVs Fintecing Gadgets Gaming Google Government & Policy Hardware Instagram Layoffs Media & Entertainment Meta Microsoft Privacy Robotics Security Social Space Startups TikTok Transportation Venture Events Startup Battlefield StrictlyVC Newsletters Podcasts Videos Partner Content TechCrunch Brand Studio Crunchboard Contact Us Welcome to Startups Weekly — your weekly recap of everything you can’t miss from the world of startups. Want it in your inbox every Friday? Sign up here. Hype can be good or bad. This week, we’ve seen startups on both sides of that fence — and being on the good side warranted large funding rounds. As the week comes to a close, it is time to tally the merits and demerits. Sparkle points: A peer-reviewed journal highlighted plans from German startup Proxima Fusion, lending new credibility to its concept and design for a working fusion power plant that can operate reliably and continuously. Oops points: Y Combinator deleted its posts about the demo from YC W25 company Optifye.ai after it went viral, and not in a good way. The startup claims to be building “Al performance monitoring for factory workers,” but others called it “sweatshops-as-a-service.” Breakthrough points: Palo Alto-based startup Inception claims to have developed a diffusion-based large language model (DLM). Diffusion models that already exist are mainly used to create images, video, and audio, while Inception hopes to compete with LLMs. This week, several startups secured funding rounds that were notably large for their respective stages, and there are new funds ready to be deployed at the growth stage. Record round: Israeli startup Quantum Machines secured one of the biggest funding rounds a quantum computing company raised to date with its $170 million Series C led by PSG Equity with participation from Intel Capital, Red Dot Capital Partners, and existing investors. Full circle: Shop Circle, which makes an app suite for e-commerce, raised a $60 million Series B round that also financed the acquisition of Aiden, an AI-powered “guided-selling” software maker. Magic arms: Polish startup Nomagic, which makes robotic arms for logistics operations, raised a $44 million Series B led by the VC arm of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). It plans to use some of the funding to reach customers in North America. Magic touch: Taktile, a New York-based startup that helps fintechs build automated decision-making workflows, closed a $54 million Series B led by Balderton Capital with participation from Index Ventures, Tiger Global, YC, Prosus Ventures, and Visionaries Club. Idea relay: Relay raised a $35 million Series A round led by London-based VC Plural to bring the “asset-free” last-mile parcel delivery model from Asia to Europe, in an approach that also reduces energy consumption and relies on e-bikes. Loved: Lovable, a fast-growing app-building AI platform coming out of Sweden, secured $15 million in a pre-Series A round led by Creandum. It also said it reached $17 million in annual recurring revenue after scaling to 30,000 paying customers with only $2 million spent. European growth: Private equity firm Thoma Bravo closed an inaugural $1.9 billion European fund to deepen its presence in the region and take fresh equity stakes in midsized software companies across the continent. Cambridge growth: Cambridge Innovation Capital (CIC), a British fund that invests exclusively in the ecosystem around the University of Cambridge, launched a $126 million opportunity fund. This week marked the third anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. This spurred a wave of Ukrainian dual-use and defense tech startups innovating on and off the battlefield, and TechCrunch rounded up several of them here. She also writes TechCrunch’s Startups Weekly newsletter, rounding up startup news every Friday.

Following significant workforce reductions in 2022 and 2023, 2024 saw more than 150,000 job cuts across 542 companies, according to independent layoffs tracker Layoffs.fyi. Large companies like Tesla, Amazon, Google, TikTok, Snap, and Microsoft conducted sizable layoffs in 2024, while smaller-sized startups also experienced cuts, and in some cases, shut down operations altogether. We’re continuing to track the industry’s layoffs into 2025 so you can see the trajectory of the cutbacks. Later this year, we will break out our 2024 and 2025 lists in order to make the trends easier to parse. By tracking these layoffs, we’re able to understand the impact on innovation across companies large and small. We’re also able to see the potential impact of businesses embracing AI and automation for jobs that had previously been considered safe. title: Workhelix taps years of research to help enterprises figure out where to apply AI | TechCrunch
text: Latest AI Amazon Apps Biotech & Health Climate Cloud Computing Commerce Crypto Enterprise EVs Fintech Fundraising Gadgets Gaming Google Government & Policy Hardware Instagram Layoffs Media & Entertainment Meta Microsoft Privacy Robotics Security Social Space Startups TikTok Transportation Venture Events Startup Battlefield StrictlyVC Newsletters Podcasts Videos Partner Content TechCrunch Brand Studio Crunchboard Contact Us AI has the power to transform how people work, but getting tangible value out of AI isn’t as easy as throwing any AI application at any workflow. It can be hard for enterprises to figure out which AI applications help their business and which are just hype. Workhelix wants to solve that problem. Workhelix is a tech-enabled service startup that works with enterprises to better understand and monitor AI automation at their companies. Workhelix breaks down a company’s employee positions into specific job functions and tasks and scores each task for its suitability for AI adoption. This helps companies build roadmaps for how and where to adopt AI and gives enterprises a way to monitor if the AI they adopted is working. Co-founder and CEO James Milin told TechCrunch that many companies are getting AI adoption wrong because they are looking to apply AI to whole divisions of their business, which is too broad to find value. “That’s not a systematic, rigorous way to adopt generative AI and is part of the reason people are frequently so disappointed,” Milin said. “But if you look at all the jobs in an organization and break them down into bundles of tasks, and then score each task for its suitability to be accelerated by generative AI, now you can come up with a really quantitative rigorous way to adopt it.” Workhelix’s methodology of breaking down roles into tasks is based on years of research into the relationship between technology and productivity by Erik Brynjolfsson (pictured above), the director of Stanford’s Digital Economy Lab and one of Workhelix’s co-founders. “In the case of a lot of our work, there’s this long tale of tasks that the machines actually don’t help that much with,” Brynjolfsson said. “You need humans to be involved. And then there’s other tasks where the machines are very helpful. And almost every project that we look at, there’s some of each of those.” Brynjolfsson told TechCrunch that he’s been researching this divide between technology and productivity for well over a decade. Prior to Workhelix, Brynjolfsson was sharing this research and methodology through published papers or through speaker gigs in board rooms, but he realized that if they added a software element, they could reach more companies. Brynjolfsson, also the co-chairman of Workhelix, paired up with Andrew McAfee, the co-director of the MIT initiative on the digital economy, and one of Brynjolfsson’s co-authors; Daniel Rock, a Wharton professor; and Milin to launch Workhelix in 2022. The company launched its product in April 2024 and has seen strong demand from enterprise customers, including Accenture, Wayfair, and Coursera, among others. Workhelix’s first dozen enterprise customers came through the door with zero paid advertising, Milin said. “This is something that they’re really hungry for,” Brynjolfsson said. “They haven’t seen anything like it before. There are consultants out there, but they don’t have these kinds of tools. We’re filling a huge gap. I think the biggest gap there is in the market.” The company recently raised a $15 million Series A round led by AIX Ventures with participation from Andrew Ng’s AI Fund, Accenture Ventures, and Bloomberg Beta, among other VCs. It also received funding from a number of angel investors, including LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman, OpenAI co-founder Mira Murati, and Jeff Dean, the chief scientist at Google DeepMind and Google Research, among others. Shaun Johnson, a founding partner at AIX Ventures, told TechCrunch that he was introduced to the company through Brynjolfsson’s work at Stanford; one of AIX Ventures’ investing partners, Christopher Manning, is the director of Stanford’s artificial intelligence laboratory. Johnson said he understood the pain point Workhelix was trying to solve right away. “Erik, Andy, and Daniel have amazing access to the Fortune 500 C-suite and access to customers,” Johnson said. “It’s extreme founder-market fit and their approach is extreme founder-product fit. That caused us to want to dive in.” Workhelix plans to put its recently raised capital toward expanding the number of tasks and KPIs its software tracks. It will also keep building up the internal tools for the data scientists that directly help enterprise customers alongside Workhelix’s product. In today’s market that’s obsessed with moving fast and automation, it’s interesting that Workhelix’s business model isn’t just software but also includes a human element, too. The company stands by this approach, although this does make it harder for it to scale. That’s because  the company wouldn’t be as effective if it were just another software platform, Milin said. “I think there’s a trillion-dollar opportunity here to create value,” Brynjolfsson said. “Not that we’re going to capture all, or even most of that, but we want to unlock that. title: ATO issues audit warning for dodgy tech and training deductions
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Tax Share The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) fears businesses are falsely claiming tax breaks created for SMEs, warning workplaces of all sizes to double-check their deduction claims. The problems might stem from big businesses pushing the boundaries, one accountant claims, but small businesses are still coming under the ATO’s microscope. The tax office last week announced business taxpayers are misjudging deduction claims under the Technology Investment Boost and the Skills and Training Boost packages. Those temporary ‘boosts’ provided an extra 20% ‘bonus’ tax deduction on eligible technology upgrades, and training for staff, respectively. Neither policy was instantly successful, as delays in enacting the tax breaks in Parliament caused uncertainty among small businesses. But official figures suggest business taxpayers eventually claimed far more than the government bargained for. Originally budgeted at a combined $1.55 billion, recent Treasury estimates state the policies will cost $1.85 billion in forgone tax revenue. Now, the tax office wants those businesses to make sure their claims are eligible. “We are seeing some small businesses incorrectly claim the boost measures due to errors or misunderstanding of the law,” said the tax office. The ATO is advising entities that may have made a mistake to amend their tax return. “If you incorrectly claim, we may get in contact with you or your tax professional,” it added. “If no action is taken, we may conduct a review and audit of your business.” Businesses with an annual aggregated turnover below $50 million can claim ‘bonus’ deductions on eligible technology expenses incurred between the evening of March 29, 2022, and 30 June 2023. The training boost covers eligible expenses from the evening of March 29, 2022, to June 3,0 2024. Businesses can claim expenses up to $100,000, resulting in a maximum deduction of $20,000. The ATO is aware of businesses with turnover in excess of $50 million claiming both the Technology Investment Boost and the Skills and Training Boost deductions. Lisa Greig, principal at Perigee Advisers and experienced tax consultant, warned against “the big end of town” claiming the deductions when they are not eligible. Businesses of that size “should have very, very competent tax advisors,” Greig told SmartCompany on Friday. “So I would say that the big end of town needs to know the rules.” Many small businesses are still not aware of the bonus deductions in the first place, continued Greig. “The client base that I look after, and the client base the other practitioners that I advise look after, we’re the ones saying, ‘Hey, claim this,’ not the other way around,” she said. Where those SMEs and sole traders are aware of the tax breaks, their deductions are relatively minor and fall well under the $100,000 expense cap, Greig continued. And in some cases, the cost of recruiting an accountant to apply for those deductions may exceed the benefit of the deduction itself, discouraging SMEs and sole traders from claiming them at all. “Small businesses take a very pragmatic approach to that sort of thing,” Greig said. Nevertheless, big businesses making ineligible claims are not the only problem. title: I Am Grounded calls out major Aussie bank for seeking freebies
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Retail Share The co-founder of Sydney-based wellness social enterprise I Am Grounded (IAG) has put one of Australia’s Big 4 banks on blast in a LinkedIn post, after the bank asked the business for hundreds of free samples in return for ‘exposure’ and ‘engagement’. Vanessa Murillo founded the IAG enterprise with Lachlan Powell in 2018, focusing on energy snacks made from upcycled coffee fruit. She says the major Australian bank, through its health and wellness partner, recently invited the business to supply hundreds of IAG’s SUPR bars for a series of upcoming wellness expos at multiple office locations. The founders, who have chosen to not publicly name the bank, were initially excited about the opportunity as it sounded like a great way to connect with a wellness-focused audience and align with a health-focused initiative. However, when they inquired about logistics and budget, the bank made it clear there was no budget available. Instead, the bank was hoping to receive hundreds of free samples in exchange for “product exposure” at the expos. Murillo told SmartCompany her first reactions were frustration and disappointment. “As a small business we don’t have an unlimited budget to gift free product,” she says. “We regularly invest in strategic sampling to get our products in front of the right audience, but when a large corporation with significant resources requests a substantial quantity of free products without offering any real value in return, it raises questions about how much they actually support small brands. “Engagement and exposure are great in theory, but they don’t pay for ingredients, packaging, shipping, or wages. “It felt like they wanted to leverage our brand’s credibility and high-quality product without contributing anything in return.” At RRP price, including shipping, fulfilling the bank’s request for the SUPR bars would have cost around $2,000 to $2,500. While this might seem like a small amount for a major corporation, Murillo says it is a serious investment for a small, independent brand. So, she and Powell tried to negotiate a deal that would cover the cost price of the bars. “We responded professionally, thanking them for reaching out and asking for further details, including how many attendees were expected, what their budget was to contribute towards the samples, what the logistics would be for shipping and distribution, and whether they would be interested in covering at least the cost of goods,” she says. “They responded by confirming that they were expecting around 500 attendees across multiple locations, that they were hoping for as many samples as possible, and that they had no budget at all to pay for the products. “Instead, they proposed two options: either slicing the bars into small tasters or giving them away as prizes for activities at the expo.” At that point, the founders “had to make a call”, she adds. “We love supporting wellness initiatives, but we also believe in valuing our product and the work that goes into creating it.” For I Am Grounded, it’s not the first time this has happened, with a well-known US-based fitness apparel brand last year requesting a few thousand free samples for one of its large-scale events. However, again, no budget was offered, only the promise of exposure. With International Women’s Day (IWD) fast approaching, many women speakers are facing a similar situation, as requests come through for them to speak for free at events. Murillo believes this highlights a larger issue that many small brands face when working with big companies. “We’ve partnered with gyms, yoga studios, and independent businesses that don’t have massive budgets, and in those cases, we’ve been happy to find ways to collaborate fairly,” she says. “But when a large corporation requests significant quantities of free products without any commitment to supporting the business in return, it’s frustrating. “If big corporations truly want to champion Australian brands, the least they can do is offer to cover costs. Otherwise, it feels like they’re leveraging their size and influence without actually investing in the businesses they claim to support.” Currently, I Am Grounded is stocked across Australia, including nationally in Woolworths, Harris Farm, several independent grocers, cafes, offices, hotels and gyms. Since launching, the social enterprise has upcycled over 33,000kg of coffee fruit into hundreds of thousands of energy bars and is actively exploring international expansion, starting with New Zealand, the MENA region, and the US. Murillo says after sharing this experience on LinkedIn, she was overwhelmed with private messages and responses from fellow brand owners who have encountered the same situation. “Many reached out to share their frustration at how frequently large companies ask small brands for free products under the guise of ‘exposure’. Others commented on how these corporations do have the means to support small businesses yet often choose not to,” she says. “The conversation has reinforced what I already believed: there needs to be real, tangible support for small businesses, not just empty promises of visibility. “If major corporations truly want to back small, values-driven brands, they need to go beyond exposure and offer genuine partnerships—whether that means covering product costs, paying for activations, or providing meaningful business opportunities. “The small business ecosystem thrives when we all support each other fairly.” Never miss a story: sign up to SmartCompany’s free daily newsletter and find our best stories on LinkedIn. title: "Let's just turn it off": Newcastle business publicly drops Afterpay
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Finance Retail Share An Australian deodorant and skincare care brand has publicly dropped Afterpay, claiming 6% transaction fees and lacklustre technical support made the buy now, pay later (BNPL) service untenable. But as merchant fees become a key issue for traders and regulators alike, Afterpay maintains its service provides businesses with more than just pay-in-four functionality. In an email sent to customers Thursday morning, Phoebe and Aaron Breckell, founders of Newcastle-based Woohoo Body, responded to customer concern over the recent decision. “We know lots of customers love the convenience and the spreading out of your expenses,” said the email. “We totally get that. “And we’d still have Afterpay available if it weren’t for the goings-on of the last few months.” Woohoo Body’s faced technical issues with its online Afterpay checkout late last year, and reached out to the fintech for support, according to the email. “We tried for months to get through to them, but they kept brushing us off,” said the pair. And like other small Afterpay merchants, Woohoo Body faced a 6% transaction fee, plus 30c, for purchases made through its BNPL system. That far surpasses the cost of credit card acceptance, which the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) estimates costs merchants an average of 1.5% per transaction. Unlike the fees associated with other card payments, merchants are currently barred from surcharging customers for the cost of BNPL payments. The RBA last year said it would “revisit” the issue of BNPL surcharging in the future. For now, that “6% is a lot for small businesses with so many other costs to absorb,” said the Woohoo Body founders. “Afterpay was costing us a small fortune – so much more than any other payment processor — and it actually felt really good to say ‘OK, let’s just turn it off!’” Speaking to SmartCompany on Thursday, Phoebe Breckell said many customers were accustomed to purchasing through Afterpay, which Woohoo Body has used since at least 2016. Despite concerns from avid Afterpay users, Breckell said other customers supported the decision. Beyond those who want to change their shopping habits, others were simply unaware of the costs borne by small businesses. “The other sentiment is people saying, ‘Oh, wow, I didn’t realise it cost you guys so much to use Afterpay,’” said Breckell. “‘I’ll be choosing other other options in the future, because we support small businesses, and we don’t want you to be incurring unnecessary costs.’” Afterpay, founded by Sydney neighbours Anthony Eisen and Nick Molnar in 2014, has long said the services it provides merchants more than justify its fees. Shoppers face no extra costs when using Afterpay, if they pay each fortnightly instalment in full and on time, and the fintech says customers are drawn to merchants offering an alternative to traditional credit. Average basket sizes are also larger for merchants using Afterpay compared to other payment methods, according to the company, which was acquired by Square (now Block) in 2021 for $39 billion. In a statement provided to SmartCompany, an Afterpay spokesperson said, “Merchant fees are attributed to the broader value merchants receive by partnering with Afterpay, which go well beyond that of typical payment systems”. This includes “access to a new budget-focused customer base, reduced fraud risk, higher order values, dedicated marketing campaigns and a global Shop Directory that provides millions of referrals every month”. When those factors are considered, Afterpay “more closely resembles marketing referral services such as Google and Facebook, and does so at a much lower cost,” they added. The spokesperson said businesses struggling with digital checkouts can access Afterpay’s merchant support team. Despite the recent Afterpay decision, Woohoo Body is keeping an open mind towards BNPL. It told customers it hopes to access instalment payments from both PayPal and Shopify’s Shop Pay in the future. Afterpay, an early pioneer in the BNPL space, is keenly aware of the challenge posed by other fintech competitors and pay-in-four solutions offered directly by the banks. In a November blog post celebrating ten years of operation, Molnar said the fintech will continue evolving to meet customer needs. “There is more to be done, and more opportunity to evolve a system where money is accessible and equitable,” he said. “We’re looking forward to working with our customers, our merchants, and our partners, to take it to the next level.” Never miss a story: sign up to SmartCompany’s free daily newsletter and find our best stories on LinkedIn. title: Mandatory monthly GST reporting for some SMEs coming April 1
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Tax Share It’s no April Fool’s joke: the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is changing how some struggling small businesses pay their GST. From April 1, 2025, the ATO will start moving some small business taxpayers from quarterly to monthly GST reporting, in an effort to boost compliance. Small businesses with a “history of not complying” with their obligations will lose the ability to calculate, report, and pay their GST amounts on a quarterly basis, said the tax office last week. Businesses that missed payments, reported their BAS late, or incorrectly reported their GST amounts are among those likely to face monthly reporting requirements. The ATO will inform those businesses of their new monthly reporting requirements in writing. The vast majority of small businesses report GST quarterly, either in full reports or as part of the Simpler BAS method. Only 4% of small businesses elected to pay GST monthly, as of March 2023. Despite the extra legwork required to report monthly, the ATO says more frequent reporting of smaller amounts will result in increased tax compliance. “Monthly reporting may make it easier for you to track your finances and business performance and make more informed decisions each month,” according to the tax office. The news comes months after ATO Commissioner Rob Heferen said the tax office is “exploring strategies to support taxpayers in getting their tax right from the start, providing more time for them to focus on their business”. The end goal: “making GST ‘just happen’”, Heferen told the Tax Institute in October last year. The decision is the ATO’s latest effort to whittle down the GST tax gap and increase system integrity. The ATO collected $85 billion in GST last financial year, according to the ATO’s annual report, $3.6 billion more than the year prior. But the net GST gap — the difference between GST owed, and GST paid — has also risen since the COVID-19 lockdown years. Some $7.9 billion, or 9% of collectible GST, went unpaid in 2022-23, up from $4.4 billion (5.5%) in 2021-2022. Not all of the ATO’s concerns are due to legitimate small businesses missing deadlines or accidentally misreporting their debts. The ATO is also clamping down on GST refunds after a disastrous fraud wave saw scammers create fake businesses to falsely claim billions of dollars in GST refunds. The tax office undertook 33,237 pre-issue refund checks for businesses that recently registered for GST in 2023-2024, according to the ATO’s annual report. title: Anyone Can Build: Qld CALD women get pre-accelerator push
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Startups Share Culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) women entrepreneurs in Queensland will get the opportunity to take their business or business idea to the next level through a new Queensland Government-funded pre-accelerator program. Anyone Can Build, which is funded by the Queensland Government as part of the Advance Queensland Accelerating Female Founders Program, will be delivered by The Creative Co-Operative in partnership with founders, investors, and entrepreneurship educator HEX. The 13-week pre-accelerator program, created specifically for CALD women in Queensland, aims to provide a safe and inclusive space to help women entrepreneurs develop their ideas, gain skills, connect with other founders and mentors, and access relevant tools and networks. Twelve spots are up for grabs for the program’s first cohort, which starts in March. Participants who complete the program will receive $1,000 of matched funding from The Creative Co-Operative, to help them pay for business set-up costs, such as creating a website or setting up an ABN. There will be a total of four cohorts over the next two years. HEX CEO and co-founder Jeanette Cheah told SmartCompany the program is a great opportunity for early-stage and idea-stage founders who are women of colour based in Queensland to get the support that they need to build their startups. “The data speaks for itself about how there’s a lack of capital flowing to great women founders,” she says. “One of the ways we can address that is to increase the pipeline of founders who are supported and have wonderful networks in place. “In a world where there’s debate beginning around the importance of diversity, equity and inclusion, investing in supporting diverse founders just makes great business sense.” Cheah says the program is looking for women of colour from all walks of life. “We are looking for people who are thinking about a technology-powered business that could scale,” she says. “It doesn’t mean that you can’t apply if you don’t know how to do technology, because that will be part of the program about how to include it in your business model. “But really, whatever problem you want to solve for society or for the people you know or from your lived experience, bring that problem to the pre-accelerator, and we will help you build a business around it.” The Creative Co-Operative founder Priyanka Ashraf said one way to start closing the economic and social gap for CALD women is by building intergenerational wealth. “Entrepreneurship, in the right conditions, allows women to navigate systemic barriers and create wealth in ways that traditional jobs may not,” she said. The cut-off date for applications for Anyone Can Build is February 28 and more information about the program is available here. title: AI-powered Tendl raises $2 million to make tendering easier
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Startups Artificial Intelligence Share Queensland AI-powered tendering platform Tendl has secured $2 million in pre-seed funding. According to the startup, the new funding will be used to expand Tendl’s development team and accelerate the company’s market growth globally. The funding round was led by Australian venture capital firm Tidal Ventures and followed by Startmate, 77 Partners, Brisbane Angels and Aussie Angels. Tendl, which was founded in 2024 by CEO Laurie Nicol and is based in Toowoomba, is an AI-based platform that is designed to streamline the tendering process for government suppliers and make it easier for businesses to write, submit and complete their tenders through automated workflows. Speaking with SmartCompany, Nicol confirmed the $2 million will be used to grow Tendl’s development team, while also expanding Tendl’s operations both in Australia and overseas. “We’ve already got customers that are tendering in the UK, the US, Canada, New Zealand and Australia, so we’re really using the investment to expand our presence in those markets and pick up a few more customers across the globe, but also growing out the development team,” he says. “Up until now, I’ve been solo. Before this investment, I did everything in the business. I wrote the software, I spoke to customers and I did all the marketing. “So it’s that opportunity to really grow the team and hire some more domain-specific experts, people who can help to run the engineering team, build the tool, and allow me to go and pursue the sales side of things. “Our goal for the expansion is really to be global and to be looking at customers that are tendering.” Tendl has already kickstarted the hiring process, with one engineer starting on Monday and another engineer lined up. According to the World Bank, the global government procurement market represents $10 trillion in annual spending. Public procurement accounts for 13% of gross domestic product in OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) countries, with $99 billion in Australian government procurement alone last year. Nicol says Tendl benefits businesses by reducing the amount of time they spend on tenders. “When tendering, you’re essentially spending hours of your staff’s time. Sometimes your most senior, most expensive and most experienced staff are writing your tender response, and there’s no guarantee that you’re going to win that tender. “Generally you might win one in three, one in five, one in 10, sometimes even less and so that means that you’re spending a lot of time on an activity that you have no guarantee you’re going to get a return.” According to Nicol, Tendl will also help improve a firm’s chances of success. “You’re able to reuse your responses better, you’re able to come up with better and new responses to tenders without having to spend hours of your most expensive resource filling out the answers,” he says. “So that’s a really big time saver for businesses, and it’s time saving on an activity where they had no guarantee of success. It’s an at-risk cost that if they don’t win, they don’t sort of see payback. So they kind of have to share that across all of their opportunities. “But equally, they can’t stop tendering, because tendering is kind of the lifeblood that, if you’re a government contractor, all of your revenue comes through tendering, and if you stop doing it, you stop making revenue.” Never miss a story: sign up to SmartCompany’s free daily newsletter and find our best stories on LinkedIn. title: Can AI fix the gender pay gap?
text: Get unlimited access. Save 70% when you subscribe today. Log in Search Search If you like this article, share it with your friends. Artificial Intelligence Startups Share Welcome back to Neural Notes, a weekly column where I look at how AI is affecting Australia. In this edition: Sydney-based startup EvenBetter.ai has secured a $500,000 investment from Shearwater Capital to help close gender pay gaps with data-driven insights. Founded by Sorrel Kesby and Ayal Steiner, EvenBetter.ai aims to move beyond compliance-focused reporting to provide organisations with actionable steps to address pay disparities. The platform identifies key drivers of pay gaps, such as leadership representation and market trends, offering recommendations to help businesses create more equitable workplaces.“Many companies acknowledge gender pay gaps but struggle to take action,” Kesby said on a call with SmartCompany. “So many different parts of a business use data — from P&Ls to recruitment tools. What doesn’t yet exist… is the ability to do that with a platform where you can cut your data, analyse your data, and create those actionable insights.”According to Kesby, EvenBetter.ai’s models analyse employer-submitted pay and workforce data, breaking down the factors contributing to pay gaps. The platform generates insights and suggests practical actions, such as adjusting hiring strategies, reviewing promotion pathways, or assessing pay structures across different roles.Kesby says a key issue with traditional pay gap reporting is that by the time businesses submit data to the Workplace Gender Equality Agency (WGEA), it’s already outdated by about nine months.EvenBetter aims to address this by helping businesses move away from a ‘set and forget’ model by providing ongoing insights that reflect their current workforce, not just a snapshot from nearly a year ago.The funding from Shearwater Capital will support EvenBetter’s next growth phase, including product development and expanding its customer base.Future iterations of the platform could include integrations with HR and accounting software, embedding pay equity insights into day-to-day business operations. EvenBetter.ai’s launch and raise coincides with WGEA’s new reporting mandates, which have increased the pressure on businesses to address pay gaps.Because of this, Kesby acknowledges not all companies will engage with the issue beyond compliance. The question is, does that matter if it’s getting results?“Some organisations will see it as a box ticking exercise… but ultimately anything we can do to improve upon the amount of people engaging properly and appropriately with this the better,” Kesby said. Another under-discussed issue is how career breaks, particularly parental leave, affect long-term earnings and promotion opportunities. “There is a long way to go in organisations in Australia,” Kesby said.She noted the true impact of leaves of absence in organisations isn’t always fully captured in existing methodologies.“I was speaking to some very senior HR leaders in a very large organisation recently and they commented on the challenges, even with the current methodology and the current reporting.”Kesby also sees an opportunity for deeper segmentation in pay equity analysis beyond gender – so long as employees are comfortable with that level of data being collected and it’s done so ethically. If there’s an organisation that has data to that level of granularity, then absolutely we can, we can cut that data. We’re building it to be scalable,” Kesby said.Ultimately, EvenBetter.ai says it aims to provide businesses with fewer excuses for inaction. “It’s great business and I think it’s great for what WGEA is promoting with the awareness of the gender pay gap in Australia,” Kesby said. title: Morrisons bolsters senior leadership team for growth and expansion - Retail Gazette
text:
﻿ Morrisons has made a series of senior leadership appointments as it continues to drive its growth strategy. The supermarket giant has poached Lidl’s chief operating officer Matt Heslop as its new director of convenience and wholesale. Heslop, who joins Morrisons next month, has spent over 20 years in a variety of roles at the German discounter, most recently as chief operating officer of Lidl UK and of its Irish business before that. In his new role, he will bring extensive experience in food retail, “delivering growth, innovation, and excellence for the customer”. Morrisons has also named Matt McLellan as group data and media director, a newly created position within the business. McLellan, who will join later this year, is currently the vice president of customer planning and proposition at Asda, where he is responsible for “the design and launch of their loyalty proposition and for developing a wide range of high-profile customer programmes and initiatives”. Meanwhile, former Carrefour director Bruno Lebon joined the supermarket in December as its non-food merchandise director, working closely with Andrew Staniland, who started as Morrisons group trading director earlier in February. Lebon brings over 39 years of experience in supermarket retailing, having most recently served as executive director of supermarkets and hypermarkets at Carrefour. In addition to the new hires, Morrisons has confirmed the formal appointment of Martin Dawson as group retail director after serving as interim operations director for retail since February 2024. Charlotte Exell has also been promoted to the newly created role of online director after her successful tenure as online operations director, where she played a key role in the growth of the grocer’s online business. Chief customer and marketing officer Rachel Eyre will return to Morrisons on 3 March following her maternity leave. The supermarket’s chief executive Rami Baitiéh said: “I’m very pleased to welcome three outstanding retailers to the Morrisons leadership team and to warmly welcome Rachel back from her maternity leave. “All the new joiners have exceptional records in their fields and bring deep experience, a history of delivering growth and a clear customer focus. As Morrisons continues its re-invigoration and growth, their skills and their passion for the customer will make them a powerful addition to our team. “Martin Dawson has made a significant impact in his new role over the last year and I am delighted to confirm him in the key role of group retail director. And Charlotte Exell has played a vital part in the recent growth of our online business and I’m confident that under her leadership Morrisons.com will go from strength to strength.” Click here to sign up to Retail Gazette‘s free daily email newsletter ﻿ Aldi Price Match became a copycat trend among the traditional supermarkets in recent years. title: Applegreen to double M&S Food network with 20 new openings in Ireland - Retail Gazette
text:
﻿ Irish roadside hospitality operator Applegreen is embarking on a multi-million-euro investment, opening 20 new M&S Food stores this year as part of a major expansion of its partnership with the British retailer. The move will see each new “shop-in-shop” location undergo a bespoke upgrade to introduce the M&S brand. By the end of 2025, Applegreen will operate 41 M&S Food stores across Ireland, nearly doubling its existing network, with plans to expand to 60 outlets in the medium term. Each of the new locations will feature over 400 of the retail giant’s food products, offering a wide selection that complements the existing Applegreen business. The range includes lunch and dinner-ready meal options, sandwiches, fresh fruit and salads, as well as popular favourites like Percy Pig sweets, M&S cookies, and Colin the Caterpillar cakes. Additionally, customers can find fresh flowers and enjoy the convenience of Click & Collect for M&S Clothing and select Home products. M&S at Applegreen Mark Ryan said: “Our partnership with M&S has been working really well over the past two years, and we’re delighted to be bringing M&S Food at Applegreen to 20 additional locations this year. “The expansion of our M&S Food partnership is one of the key elements of our growth plans in the Irish market, alongside further investment in our Braeburn Coffee brand, and significant investment in new and upgraded sites.” Click here to sign up to Retail Gazette‘s free daily email newsletter ﻿ Aldi Price Match became a copycat trend among the traditional supermarkets in recent years. title: Prospective Boots buyer eyes split of group amid sale talks - Retail Gazette
text:
﻿ Boots’ prospective buyer Sycamore Partners is planning to separate the UK retail pharmacy business from its US and healthcare arm if its bid is successful. The private equity firm is understood to be looking at a three-way split of Walgreens Boots Alliance with each having distinct capital structures, The Financial Times reported. The move would result in Walgreens, Boots and speciality pharma unit Shields Health Solutions becoming independent companies. People familiar with the matter told the title that financing for the prospective privatisation deal is not expected to be an issue despite weeks of on-off discussions with the New York-based firm. They added that talks could still fall apart in the coming weeks. Walgreens is thought to have been in talks to sell itself to private equity firm Sycamore since December, but a deal is yet to be reached. This is the third time the US owner has engaged in talks for a sale. It shelved plans for a multibillion-pound deal last June as it cut its profit outlook and announced plans to close up to 700 US stores. The group had first attempted to sell Boots back in 2022 for an estimated £7bn but abandoned the plan, deciding that offers from firms including Apollo Global Management undervalued the retailer. title: Ex-Poundland boss Austin Cooke joins Howdens - Retail Gazette
text:
﻿ Former Poundland managing director Austin Cooke has joined kitchens specialist Howdens as its new managing director for trade. The role marks a step change for Cooke, who has spent the last seven years Poundland holding several executive roles before he stepped down at the end of last month. Prior to that, he held several director positions during his more than eight year stint at KFC and four years at Phones4U. Cooke said: “The fantastic culture at Howdens is something you can see, hear, and feel. Over the past few months, I’ve had the pleasure of meeting many of the team, and I am excited to get started.” His departure at Poundland coincided with the return of its former boss Barry Williams, who is back on an interim basis to oversee a “comprehensive assessment” of Poundland and its sister chain Dealz in the Republic of Ireland. It is unclear who will replace Cooke or Williams, who is helping to formulate the new strategy for the discount chain that owner Pepco will present at its Capital Markets day on 6 March. The group is currently working with advisors at AlixPartners and is reported to be considering a sale of Poundland or a formal restructuring process that could result in job cuts and store closures. title: You.com unveils AI research agent that processes 400+ sources at once | VentureBeat
text: Join our daily and weekly newsletters for the latest updates and exclusive content on industry-leading AI coverage. Learn More You.com launched a new artificial intelligence research tool today that promises to transform how businesses conduct market research by analyzing hundreds of sources simultaneously and producing comprehensive reports in minutes instead of weeks. The tool, called Advanced Research & Insights agent (ARI), targets the $250-billion management consulting industry by automating the labor-intensive research process that typically requires teams of analysts to pore over documents for days or weeks. “The entire world of knowledge work is changing, and that’s a trillion-dollar-plus industry,” said Richard Socher, cofounder and CEO of You.com, in an interview with VentureBeat. “When every employee has instant access to comprehensive, validated insights that previously required teams of consultants and weeks of work, it changes the speed and quality of business decision-making.” What sets ARI apart from existing AI research tools is its ability to process and analyze more than 400 sources simultaneously — roughly 10 times the number that competing systems can handle, according to the company. This capability comes from a novel approach to managing context and compressing information. “The way that we’re able to find that many sources is [that] we’re taking this iterative research approach,” Bryan McCann, cofounder and CTO of You.com, told VentureBeat. “We bring back an initial set of sources, summarize and create a first research report, and then gather even more. At each step, we’re compressing that information down so we’re only adding new things.” ARI doesn’t just compile text-based reports. The system automatically generates interactive visualizations based on the data it discovers — a feature You.com claims is unique among current AI research tools. During a demonstration, Socher showed examples of automatically generated reports on renewable energy that included interactive plots showing a variety of information. “It puts together this beautiful PDF,” Socher said. “Since it talks about energy, it includes useful plots looking at market size, market growth expectations, mix of renewables and fossil fuels, solar energy growth rates.” Crucially for enterprise customers, ARI provides direct source verification for every claim. Users can click on any citation and the system will highlight exactly where the information came from, making fact-checking substantially faster. “When you click on the citation, it actually scrolls down and highlights exactly where it found that fact,” Socher demonstrated. “If your career and your job depends on the facts being right, that’s very helpful.” You.com is positioning ARI primarily for enterprise customers in research-intensive industries. Early adopters include Germany’s largest medical publisher, Wort & Bild Verlag, and global consulting firm APCO Worldwide. “We already have several hundreds of active accounts from each major consulting company,” Socher noted. “We’re excited to partner with them and help them be more productive.” Dr. Dennis Ballwieser, managing director at Wort & Bild Verlag, reported that research time “has dropped from a few days to just a few hours” through using ARI, and praised the accuracy of its results across both German and English content. ARI enters an increasingly crowded marketplace for AI research tools. Recent weeks have seen announcements of DeepSeek, Claude 3.7 from Anthropic and various other research-oriented models. Socher claims ARI differentiates itself through comprehensiveness, verification capabilities and speed. “Compared to research tools from OpenAI, for instance, ARI has 10 times the sources, but at the same time, it’s three times faster,” he said. This comparison is significant given the competitive landscape. OpenAI’s Deep Research, powered by its o3 model, leads the market with roughly an 8% hallucination rate but typically processes only 15-30 sources per query. Google launched its own Deep Research feature in December, while Perplexity and X.AI’s Grok 3 have also entered the race with similar offerings. Unlike some competing systems, ARI doesn’t make decisions about which information is most trustworthy but instead presents comprehensive findings. “ARI is optimized for comprehensiveness, so if it comes across contradicting statements, it’s much more likely to just tell you this source said this, and these sources said that,” McCann explained. “It’s not really inclined to make the decision for you as to which information is the most trustworthy.” A key aspect of ARI’s enterprise strategy is its ability to incorporate internal company data alongside public sources — creating a bridge between an organization’s proprietary information and the broader research landscape. “The biggest thing that we’re already doing now with enterprise customers is to give ARI access to their company internal data,” Socher said. “So you get all these amazing dashboards and insights right away about your own organization.” You.com is taking an unusual approach to pricing ARI, charging per report rather than based on computational resources consumed — a strategy that aligns costs with business value rather than technical implementation. “We’re looking at pricing not by token anymore, but more on a usage basis, at the actual response level,” McCann explained. “Thinking of it more like: The final piece of collateral that comes out is the thing that you’re paying for — orders of magnitude cheaper than it would have cost in the past.” This approach reflects You.com’s belief that AI usage will follow Jevons paradox: as efficiency increases, total consumption rises rather than falls. “Of course, the training costs will continue to decrease,” said Socher. “But when everyone realizes that giving a model more computational resources at run-time produces better results, it no longer makes sense to think about intelligence as a fixed property of any single model.” You.com sees ARI as just the first step in transforming how organizations approach knowledge work. The company plans to make ARI more agentic — capable of taking independent actions based on research findings. “For as long as we’ve been building it, we’ve wanted to make it more agentic,” McCann said. “If you can access almost all of the information out there about a thing, that should provide a better foundation for any decision-making on top of that information.” Socher frames You.com’s evolution around what he calls “the four A’s: accurate answers, agents and AGI.” He envisions a future when everyone becomes a manager of AI systems. “Kids that grow up with Siri and Alexa in the house already learn to assign certain questions to those things,” Socher observed. “That’s the first baby steps of becoming managers for AI.” And as those AIs get smarter, we’re going to manage them more carefully while giving them increasingly complex tasks — with research reports being just the beginning of what promises to be a profound transformation in how knowledge work gets done. title: Virtual Cards Form Cornerstones of Commerce Ecosystems
text: The surge in virtual card issuance — and the linking of banks, FinTechs, enterprises and brands to get those cards out into the market for daily use  — speaks volumes to how those cards are helping to form new commerce ecosystems for consumers and businesses. The purely digital flow, from card design to issuance to use, underpins new payment experiences. For the banks and the brands launching card products, the platform approach shortens the time to market to introduce, say, a BNPL card or a B2B-focused instrument that tailors spend management across a supply chain. The continued embrace of credentials and program management through which platforms manage compliance and risk remains a growth engine for the enablers, as cards and credentials are delivered in real time. The benefits are gaining wider recognition. In just one example, PYMNTS Intelligence found in December that, among middle-market companies — defined as firms with annual sales of between $50 million to $1 billion — 56% of executives using virtual cards have cited the improvements in working capital management as among the key advantages of using those cards. Yet the market is virtually untapped, as the data shows that just 3.3% of North American Growth Corporates use virtual cards. During Marqeta’s earnings call this week, the company said that it had struck a deal to acquire TransactPay, a BIN Sponsorship provider licensed as an E-Money Institution (EMI) in the U.K. and European Economic Area. The deal, Marqeta said in the announcement, will strengthen its card program management capabilities in the U.K. and Europe. As PYMNTS reported in tandem with earnings, EMIs are required in order to, among other things, issue prepaid and virtual cards in those regions. Concurrently, Marqeta announced that the American Express network, per Interim CEO Mike Milotich’s observations on the call, would be “a new option for credit and debit card programs” in joint efforts that would begin later this year. With a nod to how the ecosystems are taking shape, Milotich said that his company had early on “eased the burden of merchant adoption with instant issuance virtual cards. Then we were the first to help providers deliver the BNPL value proposition via card that they issue, making BNPL available anywhere a card is accepted,” and now has been working with Visa and Mastercard to deliver their recently announced flexible card credentials, which lets users switch across spending sources with that credential. “We are also making progress on Marqeta Flex with the goal of enhancing how BNPL payment options can be delivered inside payment apps and wallets, servicing them when needed within the existing payment flow,” he added. The shift toward the ecosystems can be seen in the firm’s mix shift, where the CEO said that consumer use cases are growing “much faster than single-use commercial virtual card.” Milotich also noted that in the embedded finance space, “we are trying to offer the brand more control over the value proposition, the marketing, the onboarding and have it be delivered as a truly embedded experience.” BILL.com noted in its own earnings report and conference call commentary — and with a focus on B2B — that its virtual card solution has added straight through processing provider. John Rettig, president and CFO, told analysts that within the spend and expense category, the company saw 13% card payment volume growth year over year. title: ShipBob Offers Access to Financing Program Powered by Slope
text: ShipBob now offers the users of its global supply chain and fulfillment platform for eCommerce merchants access to a new financing program. The new financing program, ShipBob Capital, is powered by JPMorgan-backed Slope and can be accessed through a Finances tab in the ShipBob dashboard, ShipBob said in a Thursday (Feb. 27) press release. ShipBob Capital offers ShipBob customers, who are small- to medium-sized business (SMB) and mid-market eCommerce merchants, access to a flexible line of credit that they can withdraw at any time, according to the release. The program offers eligible merchants approval for up to $250,000 instantly and up to millions of dollars in as little as two days; a choice of repayment plans with competitive APRs; and an application process that takes about five minutes, per the release. “With ShipBob Capital, our merchants can access the funding they need to invest in their business and scale, whether that means stocking up on more inventory or launching new products, without worrying about cash flow constraints,” ShipBob CEO and Co-founder Dhruv Saxena said in the release. Because ShipBob Capital, powered by Slope, is built into ShipBob’s platform, Slope has real-time operational insights into borrowers’ actual order volumes, inventory turnover and shipping data, which enable better underwriting and higher approvals, Slope Co-founder and Chief Product Officer Alice Deng wrote in a Thursday blog post. “Slope’s underwriting and product design make applying simple, approvals fast, and accessing capital frictionless,” Deng wrote. “It’s built directly into the ShipBob dashboard, so getting capital is as easy as managing fulfillment.” When Slope raised $30 million in an equity round in September 2023 to scale its artificial intelligence (AI)-powered payments platform for B2B businesses, the company said its platform included consumer-grade checkout processes, customer and vendor risk assessment, payment reconciliation and cash management. Slope added that its AI tools power these functions to deliver order-to-cash workflow automation. ShipBob raised $200 million in a Series E funding round in June 2021, saying that it was working with a growing number of eCommerce businesses, expanding its app store integrations and adding to its network of fulfillment centers.
